answers.answer: Some studies state this but the results are inconclusive. I have advanced tardive dyskinesia which is a potential long term side effect of antipsychotics. An MRI of my brain before I started antipsychotics and years after when I had acquired advanced tardive dyskinesia was exactly the same so this research may not prove to be clinically accurate. Tardive dyskinesia and diabetes are potential side effects of the current generation of antipsychotics (the rate of tardive being the same for all atypicals, the rate of diabetes being the least for Abilify, Fanapt and Saphris). However, if a person has schizophrenia or another psychotic disorder they need to stay in treatment. Of far more importance there is a future generation of antipsychotics in development the NMDA receptor modulates (you can find a link to a study on Wikipedia as well) that will promote a fuller recovery and not cause tardive dyskinesia or diabetes. The antipsychotic I am on glycine (google "Dr. Javitt, glycine") in myself has promoted a full recovery from schizoaffective disorder. I am the first person to use it as a primary antipsychotic (by itself) but in the standard studies it is used as an adjunct antipsychotic (along with a conventional antipsychotic) but there are other NMDA receptor modulates in Phase II FDA study that are being studied as primary antipsychotics. Its good to update yourself on research but instead of using highly tentative studies to conclude that a person doesn't need antipsychotics find out about research into new treatment modalities and find some way to advocate that more research and development be done into newer and safer treatment modalities as regards antipsychotics.

question: I have a relative who has been taking Olanzapine for a while now.  I recently found some information that suggests Olanzapine may be associated with brain shrinkage.  Stopping the Olanzapine medication is probably not a safe bet at this moment since this relative is likely to revert back to previous destructive behaviors caused by his/her mental illness, but on the other hand I think it would still be worthwhile to be informed on this as brain shrinkage is also rather concerning.These seem to suggest Olanzapine is associated with brain shrinkage (at least in monkeys):http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olanzapinehttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antipsychoticshttp://www.nature.com/npp/journal/v30/n9/pdf/1300710a.pdfhttp://www.mail-archive.com/***@****/msg23289.htmlOthers suggest that Olanzapine is actually NOT associated with brain shrinkage - rather, it's only Haloperidol that is:http://www.docguide.com/news/content.nsf/news/8525697700573E1885256DDB0056F836http://mentalhealth.about.com/b/2003/11/12/haloperidol-may-exacerbate-brain-shrinkage-in-schizophrenia.htmI realize that there is no way we can conclude that either of these claims are correct, but does anyone have any guess as to which claims are probably more accurate, and your reasons for thinking this?  My initial response upon reading the above is that Olanzapine is not associated with brain shrinkage in humans, and that it may be associated with brain shrinkage in monkeys but that there is not enough conclusive evidence that Olanzapine was a CAUSE of such brain shrinkage rather than just a correlation.  I'm still not convinced I am on the right track in thinking this though and would like some experts' opinions on this.
title: Olanzapine: Brain Shrinkage or not?
